description: Either I'm misunderstanding the whole concept of "pull-down terminal", but it doesn't seem to do the very thing it's supposed to do, i.e. pull-down the terminal on keyboard request. (worth noting that closing/pull-up did work, but that's like only 10% of usefullness)

I just love having the feature of accessing the terminal just like when accessing the console while playing Half-life back in the days.

The major gripe at the moment is that it is not compatible with Wayland as of yet, so I will patiently wait it out till that's done.
Not working on fedora 28
Thanks for the developers who fixed the segmentation fault occurring in Fedora 29. Now it works great! Please make sure it works ever and ever.
summary: One of the best terminal emulator out there with convenient features

description:
Not being able to resize with the mouse is just not good enough for serious use. 

First few columns hidden under task bar too.

I use Tilda daily in combination with tmux and a global hotkey (Ctrl+` in my case), it works really nicely. It's a pity that it doesn't work with Wayland, I hope this issue will be addressed in future updates.

There are a couple of problems that I would like to bring up:

1. After plugging in a second monitor to my laptop via HDMI and setting it as main display, Tilda doesn't adjust its window size for the new screen. As a workaround I have to to go preferences and change window size percentage from 100% to 99% and then back to 100.
2. Sometimes it quits for no reason and I have to restart. For example, when I debug in Intellj IDEA (a Java IDE) and hit a breakpoint while Tilda is open, IDEA grabs the focus and becomes a top-level window, and Tilda seems to crash/exit.
reallllllly slow, I don't know why, when I open the terminal, It loads frame by frame, it takes about 30 seconds to open it, I tried every method, but none of them works. so uninstall it.
This terminal is easy to use and can look really nice if you take the time to configure it.

I use Tilda as my default terminal emulator because it doesn't distract me from whatever else I'm doing simultaneously. It sticks to the upper left corner of my screen, with transparent background, which allows me to keep an eye on the graphic interfaces while running commands. It is possible to open different tabs if needed, which is great for frontend developing - I can run local server on one tab, testing tools on another and access git commands and navigate directories on yet another, showing and hiding everything with simple keyboard shortcuts. There's an annoying bug that keeps the window from resizing back after toggling full screen, but it's manageable.
summary: Some bugs, but overall my favorite terminal emulator

description: Great fit for my usual workflow, where I need to open a lot of terminals, but usually just for a few commands.
summary: Amazing! I wish I found this earlier

description: Once I've tweaked the settings "just so", it's what I reach for all the time. So versatile. So handy. So available.

Tried to configure height and width, options are save the program doesnt give a f just go full screen.
Tried to change the keybind to open tilda, promts a "press key" message, i press the key i want it writtes in the console without changing the key xD.

Not working for me at all...

I was able to map a shortcut to ctrl-space to make my terminal appear on top. Transparency can be set. Colors can be set. Commands can be executed. Haven't run into anything I can fault it for. But I'm new to Linux so take my thoughts with a grain of salt
summary: Does what it says. Nuff said

description: This is great terminal,. ease to use and has a lot of configurations.
summary: Great easy to use, and beautiful terminal

description:
dosen't seem to open in the desktop or sublime text

only works when mozilla is open

bit disappointing

I configure a hotkey to pulldown the terminal. It works to remove it from the screen, but it doesn't come back.
It's been working great on other distros for years.
it was a good terminal , but one day it doesn't come back by hot key.

I played with gnome terminal, guake, hyper.js and some other terminals but besides a view glitches tilde is one of the best and fastest terminals out there. With fast I mean: No Python, Ruby or Electron app!

I like it much!
summary: One of the fastest and most usable terminal emulators

description: It literally just crashes on Fedora 30.

Für mich persönlich ein Muss! Aber über mehr möglichkeiten und mehr stabilität würde ich mich sehr freuen, da gerade am Anfang bei der Konfiguration ab und zu was nicht übernommen wird oder was ganz unerwartetes passiert usw. und um nicht alles immer wieder neu zu machen, ständig die Konfigurationsdatei sichern, kann (wie gesagt am Anfang) doch sehr nervig sein. Aber danach oder sogar bei einer Neuinstallation einfach die gespeicherte Conf rein und gut ist.
Agil y versatil como se espera de una terminal flotante, con opciones de transparecia y multipestaña
And none that I like. Guake is better.
summary: It has every feature I hate

good and beatiful
